description:
This pull request updates the RADMC-3D exporter for yt-3.x. Thanks to Cameron Hummels for getting the ball rolling on this. The main changes are as follows:

1. It fixes a bug where the units were being written out to the radmc-3d files under yt-3.0.
2. It adds some additional functionality for writing out stellar sources and dealing with the resulting image files.
3. It modifies Cameron's answer test to also check the integrity of the output files by computing the total of field that is written out. 
4. It updates the narrative docs with some more information about to actually produce images from the resulting output files.
title: Updating the RADMC-3D Export module

content.raw: Yeah, that was a find / replace gone wrong. Thanks for catching it.
content.html: Yeah, that was a find / replace gone wrong. Thanks for catching it.

content.raw: There was a another change I needed to make to the docstrings to account for the fact that mu_h has units now in yt-3.0. Other than that, it still works. The dust continuum and line files basically only differ in the header. The same code is getting called under the hood.

content.raw:
Nosetest on this test fails for me with this error:

```
#!python

======================================================================
ERROR: RadMC3DValuesTest_galaxy0030_all_('gas', 'dust_density')  
----------------------------------------------------------------------
ds = yt.load(ISO_GAL)
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "/Users/chummels/src/yt-x86_64/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nose-1.3.4-py2.7.egg/nose/case.py", line 197, in run
Test
    self.test(*self.arg)
  File "/Users/chummels/src/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/utilities/answer_testing/framework.py", line 316, in __call__ 
    if self.reference_storage.reference_name is not None:
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'reference_name'
```

So I guess the `dust_density` field isn't being successfully added to the dataset before it gets passed into RadMCValuesTest?

content.raw: RadMC-3D expects this file to be `dustopac.inp` as opposed to `dust_opac.inp`.  You reference it correctly elsewhere, but you'll want to change this instance.
content.html: RadMC-3D expects this file to be dustopac.inp as opposed to dust_opac.inp. You reference it correctly elsewhere, but you'll want to change this instance.

content.raw:
you'll also want to include a numpy import:


```
#!python

import numpy as np
```

content.raw: @atmyers : this is really awesome.  Thank you for your hard work on this.  I pulled your changes and tested them out.  Following your recipe in the docs, I can produce the image you describe (with the small changes I've noted below).  The only major problem I encountered was that the test fails when I run it.  I'm not really sure what is going on there, but as per my note, it looks like the dust_density field is not sticking to the dataset, which is causing the failure.  Perhaps @ngoldbaum or @MatthewTurk have ideas on how to resolve this error?
content.html: Andrew Myers : this is really awesome. Thank you for your hard work on this. I pulled your changes and tested them out. Following your recipe in the docs, I can produce the image you describe (with the small changes I've noted below). The only major problem I encountered was that the test fails when I run it. I'm not really sure what is going on there, but as per my note, it looks like the dust_density field is not sticking to the dataset, which is causing the failure. Perhaps Nathan Goldbaum or Matthew Turk have ideas on how to resolve this error?

content.raw: Once these things are fixed, I think this is ready for merging.
content.html: Once these things are fixed, I think this is ready for merging.

content.raw:
It also seems to work for me if I run the test manually, like:


```
#!python

import yt
from yt.analysis_modules.radmc3d_export.tests.test_radmc3d_exporter import test_radmc3d_exporter_continuum
gen = test_radmc3d_exporter_continuum()
test = gen.next()
test.run()

```
content.html:
It also seems to work for me if I run the test manually, like:

import yt
from yt.analysis_modules.radmc3d_export.tests.test_radmc3d_exporter import test_radmc3d_exporter_continuum

test.run()

content.raw:
Hmm...  I was just doing:

```
#!python

$ nosetests test_radmc3d_exporter.py
```


That worked for the last iteration of this test.  But I guess one of the changes you made turned this into an answer test, so one must store the answer locally before running it again and comparing against it.  When I run with your full line:


```
#!python

$ nosetests -v --with-answer-testing analysis_modules/radmc3d_export --answer-store --local --local-dir ~/yt-test-outputs
```

It works OK.  I guess it is just strange that it gave me an error about not being able to access the `dust_density` field, when it's actually unhappy that there is no answer test against which to compare?  Weird.  So I guess this is ready to go.
content.html:
Hmm... I was just doing:

$ nosetests test_radmc3d_exporter.py

That worked for the last iteration of this test. But I guess one of the changes you made turned this into an answer test, so one must store the answer locally before running it again and comparing against it. When I run with your full line:

$ nosetests -v --with-answer-testing analysis_modules/radmc3d_export --answer-store --local --local-dir ~/yt-test-outputs

It works OK. I guess it is just strange that it gave me an error about not being able to access the dust_density field, when it's actually unhappy that there is no answer test against which to compare? Weird. So I guess this is ready to go.

content.raw: Since you're converting unit test into answer test, you need to use `yt.utilities.answer_testing.framework:requires_ds` decorator here instead of `requires_file`.
content.html: Since you're converting unit test into answer test, you need to use yt.utilities.answer_testing.framework:requires_ds decorator here instead of requires_file.

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!
